canonical_explanation.text: Combustion is a chemical process in which a substance (fuel) reacts with oxygen to produce heat and light. Three conditions are necessary for combustion: the presence of a combustible substance (fuel), air (oxygen), and heating to the ignition temperature. The ignition temperature is the minimum temperature at which a substance catches fire. Substances with low ignition temperatures, such as petrol, alcohol, and LPG, are called inflammable substances. There are different types of combustion: rapid combustion (occurs quickly with external heat, like burning of gas), spontaneous combustion (occurs on its own without external heat, like forest fires), and explosion (sudden reaction with large amounts of gas, heat, light, and sound). A candle flame has three zones: the dark zone (innermost, unburnt wax vapours, least hot), the luminous zone (middle, partial combustion, yellow, moderately hot), and the non-luminous zone (outermost, complete combustion, blue, hottest). Calorific value is the amount of heat produced per unit mass of a fuel, measured in kJ/kg. An ideal fuel has a high calorific value, is easily available, burns without pollution, and is easy to store and transport.
rules: Combustion requires: fuel + oxygen (air) + ignition temperature.
Ignition temperature is the minimum temperature at which a substance catches fire.
Inflammable substances have very low ignition temperatures (e.g., petrol, LPG, alcohol).
Rapid combustion: burns quickly when heated (e.g., gas stove).
Spontaneous combustion: catches fire without external heating (e.g., phosphorus in air).
Explosion: sudden reaction producing gas, heat, light, and sound (e.g., firecrackers).
Fire triangle: fuel, heat, and oxygen — remove any one to extinguish fire.
Candle flame zones: dark (innermost, coolest), luminous (middle, yellow), non-luminous (outermost, hottest, blue).
Calorific value = heat produced per unit mass of fuel (kJ/kg).
Ideal fuel: high calorific value, low cost, easy storage, minimal pollution.

questions.question_text: What is combustion?

options.text: A chemical process in which a substance reacts with oxygen giving heat and light

questions.explanation_correct: Combustion is a chemical process in which a substance (fuel) reacts with oxygen to produce heat and light. Common examples include burning of wood, coal, LPG gas, and petrol.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Melting, dissolving, and freezing are physical processes, not combustion. Combustion is specifically the chemical reaction of a substance with oxygen that produces heat and light energy.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a condition necessary for combustion?
questions.explanation_correct: Water is not necessary for combustion — in fact, water is often used to extinguish fire. The three conditions required for combustion are: a combustible substance (fuel), air (oxygen), and heating the substance to its ignition temperature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Combustion requires fuel, oxygen, and ignition temperature — these form the fire triangle. Water actually helps put out fires and is not a condition for combustion. It is used as a fire-extinguishing agent.

questions.question_text: The three components of the fire triangle are:
questions.explanation_correct: The fire triangle consists of fuel (combustible material), heat (to reach ignition temperature), and oxygen (from air). All three must be present for fire to start and continue. Removing any one component will extinguish the fire.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Water and carbon dioxide are used to extinguish fires, not to sustain them. Nitrogen is an inert gas that does not support combustion. The fire triangle specifically requires fuel, heat, and oxygen.

questions.question_text: Which type of combustion occurs quickly when heat is applied from outside?
questions.explanation_correct: Rapid combustion occurs quickly when a substance is heated from an external source. Examples include burning of gas on a stove (when a matchstick provides heat) or burning of a candle. The substance burns rapidly once ignited.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Spontaneous combustion occurs without external heat. Explosion is a very sudden combustion with large gas production. Rapid combustion specifically requires external heating and then burns quickly once ignited.

questions.question_text: Which type of combustion occurs without any external heating?
questions.explanation_correct: Spontaneous combustion occurs without any external source of heat. The substance catches fire on its own. For example, white phosphorus catches fire at room temperature in air, and stored hay can spontaneously combust due to slow oxidation producing heat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rapid combustion requires external heat. Explosion is a sudden reaction, not necessarily without external heat. Complete combustion refers to burning with sufficient oxygen. Spontaneous combustion uniquely occurs without any external heating.

questions.question_text: What is the ignition temperature of a substance?

options.text: The temperature at which a substance melts
The minimum temperature at which a substance catches fire
The temperature at which a substance boils
The maximum temperature a substance can reach

questions.explanation_correct: The ignition temperature is the minimum temperature at which a substance catches fire and starts burning. Different substances have different ignition temperatures — paper has a lower ignition temperature than wood.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ignition temperature is not about melting, boiling, or maximum temperature. It is specifically the lowest temperature at which a substance starts to burn when exposed to air (oxygen).

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an inflammable substance?
questions.explanation_correct: Petrol is an inflammable substance because it has a very low ignition temperature and catches fire easily. Other inflammable substances include alcohol, LPG, and kerosene. Stone, glass, and iron nails are not easily combustible.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Stone, glass, and iron nails are non-combustible or have very high ignition temperatures. Petrol has a very low ignition temperature, making it highly inflammable and requiring careful storage away from fire sources.

questions.question_text: Why is it dangerous to store petrol near a fire?

options.text: Petrol has a very low ignition temperature and catches fire easily

questions.explanation_correct: Petrol is dangerous near fire because it has a very low ignition temperature — it can catch fire easily even from a small spark. Its vapours are also highly flammable, making it extremely hazardous near any heat source.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While petrol does evaporate, the danger is specifically because of its low ignition temperature. The vapours can ignite easily from even a small spark, leading to a fire or explosion. This is why petrol pumps display 'No Smoking' signs.

questions.question_text: How does a fire extinguisher work?

options.text: By adding more fuel to the fire
By cutting off the supply of air (oxygen), fuel, or lowering temperature below ignition point
By adding oxygen to the fire

questions.explanation_correct: A fire extinguisher works by removing one or more components of the fire triangle. Water-based extinguishers lower the temperature below ignition point. CO2 extinguishers cut off the oxygen supply. Foam extinguishers smother the fuel to cut off air.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Adding more fuel or oxygen would make the fire worse. Increasing temperature would also worsen it. Fire extinguishers work by removing one of the three essential conditions: fuel, oxygen, or heat (lowering temperature below ignition point).

questions.question_text: Why does a matchstick catch fire on rubbing against the matchbox?

options.text: Friction produces heat that reaches the ignition temperature of the matchstick head

questions.explanation_correct: When a matchstick is rubbed against the rough surface of a matchbox, friction generates heat. This heat is enough to raise the temperature of the chemicals on the matchstick head to their ignition temperature, causing them to catch fire.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The matchstick is not already burning. The matchbox does not provide oxygen (air provides oxygen). The matchstick does not contain water. The key mechanism is friction generating enough heat to reach the ignition temperature of the matchstick head chemicals.

questions.question_text: Which zone of a candle flame is the hottest?
questions.explanation_correct: The non-luminous zone (outermost zone, blue in colour) is the hottest part of a candle flame. This is where complete combustion occurs because this zone gets the maximum supply of oxygen from the surrounding air.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The dark zone is the coolest. The luminous zone is moderately hot. The zones are not equal in temperature. The non-luminous (outermost) zone is the hottest because complete combustion takes place there with maximum oxygen supply.

questions.question_text: The yellow, bright part of a candle flame is called the:
questions.explanation_correct: The yellow, bright part of a candle flame is called the luminous zone. It is the middle zone where partial combustion occurs. Unburnt carbon particles glow and give the bright yellow light characteristic of this zone.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The dark zone is the innermost, non-glowing part. The non-luminous zone is the outermost, blue part where complete combustion occurs. The luminous (meaning 'light-giving') zone is the bright yellow middle section.

questions.question_text: In the dark zone of a candle flame:

options.text: Unburnt wax vapours are present and it is the least hot zone
The flame is blue in colour

questions.explanation_correct: The dark zone is the innermost zone of the candle flame, closest to the wick. It contains unburnt wax vapours, has no combustion occurring, and is the least hot (coolest) part of the flame.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Complete combustion occurs in the outermost non-luminous zone, not the dark zone. The highest temperature is in the outermost zone. The blue colour is also in the outermost zone. The dark zone is cool and contains unburnt vapours.

questions.question_text: Goldsmiths use the outermost zone of a flame for melting gold. Why?

options.text: Because it is the brightest zone
Because it is the coolest zone
Because it is the hottest zone where complete combustion occurs
Because it produces the most smoke

questions.explanation_correct: Goldsmiths use the outermost non-luminous zone because it is the hottest part of the flame. Complete combustion occurs here, producing maximum heat needed to melt gold (melting point 1064 degrees Celsius). This zone is blue in colour.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The brightest zone is the luminous middle zone, not the hottest. The coolest zone is the dark inner zone. The outermost zone actually produces the least smoke due to complete combustion. Goldsmiths use it specifically for its maximum temperature.

questions.question_text: What is calorific value?

options.text: The colour of the flame produced by a fuel
The amount of heat produced on complete combustion of one kilogram of fuel
The ignition temperature of a fuel

questions.explanation_correct: Calorific value is the amount of heat energy produced on complete combustion of one kilogram of a fuel. It is expressed in kJ/kg. A higher calorific value means the fuel produces more heat per kilogram.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Calorific value is not about flame colour, fuel weight, or ignition temperature. It is a measure of how much heat energy a fuel can produce per unit mass, making it a key indicator of fuel efficiency.

questions.question_text: The unit of calorific value is:
questions.explanation_correct: The calorific value is measured in kJ/kg (kilojoules per kilogram). This unit represents the amount of heat energy (in kilojoules) produced by burning one kilogram of fuel.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Degrees Celsius measures temperature. Metres per second measures speed. Kilogram measures mass. kJ/kg is the correct unit for calorific value as it measures heat energy per unit mass of fuel.

questions.question_text: Which of the following fuels has the highest calorific value?
questions.explanation_correct: LPG has the highest calorific value among the given options (about 55,000 kJ/kg). This means burning 1 kg of LPG produces more heat than burning 1 kg of wood, coal, or cow dung.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wood (about 17,000 kJ/kg), coal (about 25,000-33,000 kJ/kg), and cow dung (about 6,000-8,000 kJ/kg) all have lower calorific values than LPG (about 55,000 kJ/kg). LPG is therefore a more efficient fuel.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a characteristic of an ideal fuel?

options.text: Produces a lot of smoke and pollution
High calorific value, easy to store, and causes minimal pollution
Very expensive and difficult to transport

questions.explanation_correct: An ideal fuel should have a high calorific value (produces more heat), be easily available, cheap, easy to store and transport, burn completely without leaving residue, and cause minimal air pollution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A low calorific value means less heat — not ideal. Producing smoke and pollution is a disadvantage. Being expensive and hard to transport makes a fuel impractical. An ideal fuel is efficient, clean, affordable, and easy to handle.

questions.question_text: Forest fires sometimes start on their own during extremely hot summers. This is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Forest fires starting on their own during hot weather are an example of spontaneous combustion. The heat from the sun and the internal heat generated by decomposing organic matter can raise the temperature of dry leaves and wood to their ignition temperature without any external flame.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rapid combustion requires an external heat source to start. Explosion involves sudden gas production. Incomplete combustion is about insufficient oxygen. When fire starts on its own without external ignition, it is spontaneous combustion.

questions.question_text: Bursting of firecrackers is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Bursting of firecrackers is an example of explosion. An explosion is a sudden combustion reaction that produces large amounts of gas, heat, light, and a loud sound. The reaction happens so fast that the gases expand rapidly, creating the 'bang'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Firecrackers do not burn slowly (rapid or slow combustion) or catch fire on their own (spontaneous). They undergo an extremely fast combustion reaction — an explosion — producing a sudden release of gas, heat, light, and sound.

questions.question_text: Why is water not used to extinguish oil fires?

options.text: Water is heavier than oil and sinks below, and oil continues to burn on top
Water does not exist near oil fires

questions.explanation_correct: Water should not be used on oil fires because water is denser than oil. Water sinks below the burning oil, and the oil floats on top and continues to burn. Additionally, the water can cause the burning oil to splash and spread the fire further.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The reason is not cost or availability. Water does not make oil burn faster chemically, but since water is heavier than oil, it sinks below the oil layer. The oil remains on top, exposed to air, and keeps burning. CO2 or foam extinguishers are used for oil fires instead.

questions.question_text: What happens when you place a glass plate over a burning candle? Explain the principle.

options.text: The flame burns brighter because glass reflects heat
The candle goes out because the oxygen supply is cut off

questions.explanation_correct: When a glass plate (or jar) is placed over a burning candle, it cuts off the supply of oxygen (air) to the flame. Without oxygen, combustion cannot continue, and the candle flame goes out. This demonstrates that oxygen is essential for combustion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Glass does not make the flame brighter or melt at candle temperature. The flame definitely goes out. The principle is that by covering the candle, the oxygen inside is consumed and no fresh air can enter, so combustion stops.

questions.question_text: Paper catches fire more easily than wood. This is because:

options.text: Paper has a higher ignition temperature than wood
Paper has a lower ignition temperature than wood
Paper contains more water than wood

questions.explanation_correct: Paper catches fire more easily than wood because it has a lower ignition temperature. Less heat is needed to raise paper to its ignition temperature compared to wood. This is why paper burns quickly while wood takes longer to catch fire.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A higher ignition temperature would mean paper is harder to ignite, not easier. Paper does not contain more water than wood. Paper is definitely combustible. The lower ignition temperature of paper explains why it catches fire more readily.

questions.question_text: When you hold a metal plate in the luminous zone of a candle flame, a black deposit forms. This deposit is:

options.text: Unburnt carbon particles (soot) due to incomplete combustion

questions.explanation_correct: The black deposit is unburnt carbon particles (soot). In the luminous zone, incomplete combustion occurs due to insufficient oxygen. The carbon particles in the fuel vapour do not fully burn and are deposited as black soot on the metal plate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The deposit is not ash, metal oxide, or wax. It is soot — unburnt carbon particles produced because incomplete combustion occurs in the luminous zone. If the plate were held in the non-luminous zone (complete combustion), no soot would be deposited.

questions.question_text: Why is LPG a better domestic fuel than wood?

options.text: LPG has a higher calorific value, burns cleanly, and does not produce smoke
LPG has a lower calorific value than wood

questions.explanation_correct: LPG is a better domestic fuel than wood because it has a much higher calorific value (about 55,000 kJ/kg vs 17,000 kJ/kg for wood), burns with a clean blue flame without producing smoke or soot, and does not leave solid residue. Wood burning produces smoke, soot, and air pollution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: LPG is lighter than wood, not heavier. It is not found in forests. It has a much higher calorific value, not lower. LPG's cleaner combustion and higher energy output make it superior to wood as a domestic fuel.

questions.question_text: A liquid with a very low ignition temperature catches fire easily and burns rapidly. Such a substance is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Substances with very low ignition temperatures that catch fire easily are called inflammable (or flammable) substances. Examples include petrol, alcohol, LPG, and kerosene. These must be stored and handled with great care.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Non-combustible substances cannot burn. Fire-resistant substances resist fire. Inert substances do not react. Inflammable substances are those that ignite easily because their ignition temperature is very low.

questions.question_text: Why does a wet blanket help in extinguishing fire?

options.text: It provides more fuel to the fire
It covers the fire, cutting off oxygen supply, and the water lowers the temperature
It increases the ignition temperature of the fuel
It adds oxygen to the fire

questions.explanation_correct: A wet blanket helps extinguish fire in two ways: it covers the burning material, cutting off the supply of oxygen (air) to the flame, and the water in the blanket absorbs heat, lowering the temperature below the ignition point. Both actions remove components of the fire triangle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A wet blanket does not provide fuel, add oxygen, or change the ignition temperature of the fuel. It works by removing two of the three fire triangle components: cutting off oxygen by covering, and removing heat through the cooling effect of water.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of an ideal fuel?

options.text: Produces large amounts of smoke and ash

questions.explanation_correct: An ideal fuel should NOT produce large amounts of smoke and ash. An ideal fuel burns cleanly and completely, producing minimal pollution. Smoke and ash indicate incomplete combustion and cause air pollution and health problems.
questions.explanation_incorrect: High calorific value, easy storage/transport, and reasonable cost are all desirable characteristics of an ideal fuel. Producing smoke and ash is a negative quality — ideal fuels should burn cleanly with minimal residue and pollution.

questions.question_text: Cooking food on a gas stove, the blue flame indicates:

options.text: Complete combustion is occurring with sufficient oxygen
The gas is about to run out

questions.explanation_correct: A blue flame on a gas stove indicates complete combustion with sufficient oxygen supply. The fuel is burning fully, producing maximum heat and no soot. If the flame turns yellow, it indicates incomplete combustion and insufficient oxygen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A blue flame is a sign of efficient, complete combustion — not incomplete combustion, low gas, or malfunction. A yellow flame would indicate problems. The blue colour shows the gas is burning properly with adequate oxygen.

questions.question_text: What type of fire extinguisher is best for electrical fires?
questions.explanation_correct: CO2 fire extinguishers are best for electrical fires because CO2 is a non-conductor of electricity and does not leave any residue. Water should never be used on electrical fires as water conducts electricity and can cause electric shock.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Water conducts electricity and is dangerous for electrical fires. Sand can be used but is not as effective. A wet blanket also involves water. CO2 extinguishers are the safest choice because carbon dioxide does not conduct electricity and smothers the fire by cutting off oxygen.

questions.question_text: Which of the following substances is non-combustible?
questions.explanation_correct: Sand is a non-combustible substance — it does not burn. This is why sand is sometimes used to extinguish fires by covering the burning material and cutting off the oxygen supply. Kerosene, paper, and coal are all combustible.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Kerosene, paper, and coal are all combustible substances that can burn. Sand (silicon dioxide) is non-combustible and is actually used to put out small fires by smothering them.

questions.question_text: The calorific value of hydrogen is approximately 150,000 kJ/kg. Why is hydrogen not commonly used as a fuel despite this high value?

options.text: Hydrogen is not available on earth
Hydrogen is too heavy to store
Hydrogen is highly explosive and difficult to store and transport safely

questions.explanation_correct: Despite having the highest calorific value, hydrogen is not commonly used as a fuel because it is highly explosive and difficult to store and transport safely. It forms explosive mixtures with air and requires special pressurised containers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hydrogen exists abundantly in water molecules and can be produced. It is the lightest element, not heavy. It does burn readily. The challenge is that hydrogen is highly flammable and explosive, making safe storage and transportation very difficult and expensive.

questions.question_text: Combustion is a chemical reaction in which a substance reacts with oxygen to give heat and light.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Combustion is indeed a chemical reaction between a combustible substance (fuel) and oxygen that produces heat and light. Examples include burning of wood, paper, LPG, and other fuels.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement accurately describes combustion. It is a chemical reaction, not a physical change, and it requires oxygen and produces both heat and light energy.

questions.question_text: All substances have the same ignition temperature.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Different substances have different ignition temperatures. For example, paper has a lower ignition temperature than wood, and petrol has a much lower ignition temperature than coal. This is why some substances catch fire more easily than others.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Different substances require different minimum temperatures to start burning. Petrol ignites at a much lower temperature than wood. This variation in ignition temperatures is why some materials are more flammable than others.

questions.question_text: The innermost zone of a candle flame is the hottest part.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. The innermost zone (dark zone) is the least hot (coolest) part of the candle flame. It contains unburnt wax vapours. The hottest part is the outermost non-luminous zone where complete combustion occurs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The temperature increases from the inside to the outside of the flame. The innermost dark zone is the coolest, the middle luminous zone is moderately hot, and the outermost non-luminous zone is the hottest.

questions.question_text: A fuel with a higher calorific value produces more heat per kilogram than a fuel with a lower calorific value.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Calorific value measures the heat energy produced per kilogram of fuel. A higher calorific value means more heat is produced for the same mass of fuel, making it a more efficient fuel.
questions.explanation_incorrect: By definition, calorific value is the heat produced per unit mass. A higher number means more heat per kilogram. For example, LPG (55,000 kJ/kg) produces more heat per kg than wood (17,000 kJ/kg).

questions.question_text: Water is used to extinguish all types of fires including oil fires and electrical fires.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Water should NOT be used on oil fires (because water sinks below oil and oil keeps burning on top) or electrical fires (because water conducts electricity and can cause electric shock). CO2 or foam extinguishers are used instead.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Water is suitable only for certain types of fires (like wood, paper, and fabric fires). For oil fires, water causes the oil to splash and spread. For electrical fires, water conducts electricity, creating an electrocution hazard.

questions.question_text: LPG and petrol are examples of inflammable substances because they have very low ignition temperatures.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. LPG and petrol are inflammable substances because they have very low ignition temperatures, meaning they catch fire very easily. This is why they require careful handling and storage away from heat sources.
questions.explanation_incorrect: LPG and petrol do indeed have very low ignition temperatures, which is precisely what makes them inflammable. Their vapours can ignite from even a small spark, which is why safety precautions are essential.

questions.question_text: The minimum temperature at which a substance catches fire is called its ___ temperature.
questions.explanation_correct: The ignition temperature is the minimum temperature at which a combustible substance starts to burn. Different substances have different ignition temperatures — inflammable substances have very low ignition temperatures.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 'ignition'. This temperature is the threshold at which a substance can sustain combustion in the presence of oxygen. Below this temperature, the substance will not catch fire.

questions.question_text: The outermost zone of a candle flame is called the ___ zone.
questions.explanation_correct: The outermost zone of a candle flame is the non-luminous zone. It appears blue in colour and is the hottest part of the flame because complete combustion occurs here with maximum oxygen supply.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 'non-luminous'. This zone is blue, hottest, and involves complete combustion. 'Non-luminous' means it does not produce bright visible light like the luminous zone.

questions.question_text: The amount of heat produced by the complete combustion of 1 kg of a fuel is called its ___ value.
questions.explanation_correct: The calorific value of a fuel is the amount of heat energy produced when one kilogram of the fuel undergoes complete combustion. It is measured in kJ/kg and indicates the fuel's efficiency.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 'calorific'. This term comes from 'calorie' (a unit of heat). Calorific value helps compare the heat-producing capacity of different fuels.

questions.question_text: A combustion reaction that occurs without any external heat is called ___ combustion.
questions.explanation_correct: Spontaneous combustion occurs without the application of external heat. The substance catches fire on its own due to heat generated by slow oxidation or chemical reactions within the material. Examples include forest fires in extreme heat and white phosphorus igniting in air.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 'spontaneous'. This type of combustion is different from rapid combustion (needs external heat) and explosion (sudden reaction). Spontaneous means it happens on its own without any outside ignition.

questions.question_text: Substances that have very low ignition temperatures and catch fire easily are called ___ substances.
questions.explanation_correct: Inflammable (or flammable) substances have very low ignition temperatures and catch fire easily. Examples include petrol, alcohol, LPG, and acetone. These substances must be stored carefully away from heat and fire sources.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 'inflammable'. These are substances that ignite easily because very little heat is needed to raise their temperature to the ignition point. Safety labels on containers of such substances warn about their flammability.

questions.question_text: A student noticed that a gas stove flame turned from blue to yellow. What does this indicate?

options.text: Incomplete combustion is occurring due to insufficient oxygen supply

questions.explanation_correct: A yellow flame on a gas stove indicates incomplete combustion due to insufficient oxygen supply. The air holes of the burner may be blocked or partially closed. Incomplete combustion produces less heat, more soot, and carbon monoxide (a poisonous gas).
questions.explanation_incorrect: A yellow flame is not a sign of proper working. Blue flame indicates complete combustion, not yellow. The yellow colour comes from glowing carbon particles that are not fully burned, indicating the air supply needs to be adjusted.

questions.question_text: At petrol pumps, you see 'No Smoking' signs. This is because:

options.text: Petrol vapours are highly inflammable and can catch fire from a cigarette spark
It is a general rule for public places

questions.explanation_correct: Petrol has a very low ignition temperature and its vapours are highly inflammable. A lit cigarette or even a small spark can ignite petrol vapours, causing a fire or explosion. The 'No Smoking' sign is a critical safety measure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While smoking is bad for health, the specific reason for 'No Smoking' at petrol pumps is safety. Petrol vapours present in the air near the pump can ignite from the heat of a cigarette, potentially causing a catastrophic fire or explosion.

questions.question_text: Incomplete combustion of fuels produces a poisonous gas. Which gas is it?
questions.explanation_correct: Carbon monoxide (CO) is the poisonous gas produced during incomplete combustion of carbon-containing fuels. It is colourless and odourless, making it very dangerous. It reduces the oxygen-carrying capacity of blood and can cause death.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Carbon dioxide is produced in complete combustion and is not as toxic. Nitrogen and oxygen are atmospheric gases, not products of combustion. Carbon monoxide, produced during incomplete combustion, is the highly poisonous gas that can be lethal.

questions.question_text: Why does coal take longer to catch fire compared to paper?

options.text: Coal has a higher ignition temperature than paper

questions.explanation_correct: Coal takes longer to catch fire because it has a higher ignition temperature than paper. More heat energy is needed to raise coal to its ignition temperature. Paper, having a lower ignition temperature, catches fire more quickly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Coal does burn, is heavier than paper, and the reason is not water content. The key factor is ignition temperature — coal requires more heat to reach its higher ignition temperature compared to paper's lower ignition temperature.

questions.question_text: How many zones does a candle flame have?
questions.explanation_correct: A candle flame has three distinct zones: the dark zone (innermost, least hot, unburnt vapours), the luminous zone (middle, yellow, moderately hot, partial combustion), and the non-luminous zone (outermost, blue, hottest, complete combustion).
questions.explanation_incorrect: A candle flame does not have one, two, or four zones. It has exactly three zones, each with different characteristics of temperature, colour, and combustion state.

questions.question_text: An ideal fuel exists in reality and is readily available for everyday use.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. No ideal fuel exists in reality. Every known fuel has some disadvantages — some produce pollution, some are expensive, some are difficult to store, and some have low calorific values. An ideal fuel is a theoretical concept against which real fuels are compared.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While we use many different fuels, none of them perfectly meets all the criteria of an ideal fuel (high calorific value, no pollution, cheap, easy to store and transport, readily available). The ideal fuel is a theoretical benchmark.

questions.question_text: The three sides of the fire triangle are fuel, ___, and oxygen.
questions.explanation_correct: The fire triangle consists of fuel, heat, and oxygen. All three must be present for combustion to occur. Removing any one of these three components will extinguish the fire — this is the principle behind fire-fighting methods.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 'heat'. The fire triangle has three essential components: fuel (combustible substance), heat (to reach ignition temperature), and oxygen (supporter of combustion). Fire-fighting works by removing one of these three.
